title: Psalms Chapter 8 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 8 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 8 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 8.

questions.question: Who is the author of Psalms 8 according to the text?
questions.explanation: Psalms 8:1 states that this is a Psalm of David.

questions.question: According to Psalms 8:1, where has God set His glory?
questions.explanation: Psalms 8:1 says God has set His glory above the heavens.

questions.question: What has God ordained strength out of, according to Psalms 8:2?
options: The mouth of babes and sucklings
questions.correctAnswer: The mouth of babes and sucklings
questions.explanation: Psalms 8:2 mentions strength ordained out of the mouth of babes and sucklings.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 8:3 mentions the moon and the stars as the work of God's fingers.
questions.explanation: Psalms 8:3 describes the moon and the stars as the work of God's fingers.

questions.question: What question is asked about man in Psalms 8:4?
options: What is man, that thou art mindful of him?
Who is man, that he can see God?
Where is man, that he might find peace?
Why is man, that he should suffer?
questions.correctAnswer: What is man, that thou art mindful of him?
questions.explanation: Psalms 8:4 asks, 'What is man, that thou art mindful of him?'

questions.question: According to Psalms 8:5, man was made a little lower than what?
questions.explanation: Psalms 8:5 states that man was made a little lower than the angels.

questions.question: What has man been crowned with, according to Psalms 8:5?
questions.explanation: Psalms 8:5 says man is crowned with glory and honour.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Psalms 8:6: 'Thou madest him to have dominion over the _____ of thy hands.'
questions.explanation: Psalms 8:6 states that man has dominion over the works of God's hands.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 8:7 includes oxen among the creatures under man's dominion.
questions.explanation: Psalms 8:7 lists oxen as among the creatures under man's feet.

questions.question: Which of the following creatures is NOT mentioned in Psalms 8 as being under man's dominion?
questions.explanation: Psalms 8:7-8 mentions sheep, oxen, beasts of the field, fowl of the air, and fish of the sea, but not serpents of the desert.

questions.question: What phrase is repeated in Psalms 8:1 and Psalms 8:9 about the Lord's name?
options: How excellent is thy name in all the earth!
Blessed be the name of the Lord
questions.correctAnswer: How excellent is thy name in all the earth!
questions.explanation: Both Psalms 8:1 and Psalms 8:9 say 'O LORD our Lord, how excellent is thy name in all the earth!'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 8 says that God visits the son of man.
questions.explanation: Psalms 8:4 mentions God visiting the son of man.

questions.question: According to Psalms 8:8, what passes through the paths of the seas?
questions.explanation: Psalms 8:8 says 'and whatsoever passeth through the paths of the seas' referring to fish of the sea.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the strength ordained from babes and sucklings according to Psalms 8:2?
options: To still the enemy and the avenger
questions.correctAnswer: To still the enemy and the avenger
questions.explanation: Psalms 8:2 explains strength from babes is ordained to still the enemy and the avenger.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Psalms 8:6: 'Thou hast put all things under his _____.'
questions.explanation: Psalms 8:6 says God has put all things under man's feet.

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 8 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 8 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A believer is feeling insignificant and wonders about their value to God. Based on Psalms 8, what biblical truth can you share about human worth?
options: Man is made a little lower than the angels and crowned with glory and honor.
Man is the highest creature and should rule over angels.
Man is insignificant compared to the stars and heavens.
Man is only valuable if he is wealthy and powerful.
questions.correctAnswer: Man is made a little lower than the angels and crowned with glory and honor.
questions.explanation: Psalms 8:4-5 teaches that though humans are small in the universe, God has crowned them with glory and honor, showing their precious value to Him.

questions.question: How does Psalms 8 encourage believers to trust God in times of opposition or spiritual attack?
options: God ordains strength even from the mouths of babes to silence enemies.
Believers must rely solely on their own strength to overcome enemies.
Enemies will always triumph over the righteous.
Prayer is unnecessary when facing enemies.
questions.correctAnswer: God ordains strength even from the mouths of babes to silence enemies.
questions.explanation: Psalms 8:2 shows that God uses unexpected means, like the weakness of children, to still enemies, encouraging trust in His power over opposition.

questions.question: In what way does Psalms 8 teach humility despite human dominion over creation?
options: Man is made just a little lower than the angels, not above them.
Man is the supreme ruler over God.
Man is greater than the heavens and stars.
Man should boast in his power over animals.
questions.correctAnswer: Man is made just a little lower than the angels, not above them.
questions.explanation: Psalms 8:5 highlights that humans, though given dominion, are still positioned just below angels, reminding believers to remain humble despite authority.

questions.question: A fellow believer asks how to live with gratitude daily. What truth from Psalms 8 can you share to inspire thanksgiving?
options: Recognize God's excellence and glory in all the earth and heavens.
Focus only on personal achievements and ignore God's works.
Be thankful only when life is easy and comfortable.
Gratitude is unnecessary because God is distant.
questions.correctAnswer: Recognize God's excellence and glory in all the earth and heavens.
questions.explanation: Psalms 8:1 and 8:9 praise God's excellent name and glory throughout creation, encouraging believers to cultivate gratitude by acknowledging God's majesty.

questions.question: How does Psalms 8 teach us about stewardship and responsibility in daily work?
options: God gave humans dominion over all creatures, so we must manage His creation responsibly.
Humans should exploit creation without regard for God’s design.
Work is unimportant and unrelated to faith.
Only priests are responsible for God's creation.
questions.correctAnswer: God gave humans dominion over all creatures, so we must manage His creation responsibly.
questions.explanation: Psalms 8:6-8 shows God placing all things under man's feet, indicating a trusted role that calls for faithful stewardship in work and daily life.

questions.question: When facing trials, how can recalling Psalms 8 help a believer persevere?
options: Remember that God’s glory is above the heavens and He is mindful of you.
Focus on the difficulties without trusting God’s care.
Give up because God is indifferent to human struggles.
Rely only on personal strength to endure trials.
questions.correctAnswer: Remember that God’s glory is above the heavens and He is mindful of you.
questions.explanation: Psalms 8:1 and 8:4 remind believers that God’s glory is supreme and He is mindful of humans, encouraging trust and perseverance through hardships.

questions.question: How does Psalms 8 encourage believers to approach prayer and worship?
options: With awe and recognition of God's excellent name throughout all the earth.
Ignoring God’s majesty and focusing on self.
questions.correctAnswer: With awe and recognition of God's excellent name throughout all the earth.
questions.explanation: Psalms 8:1 and 8:9 emphasize praising the Lord’s excellent name, inspiring reverent worship and heartfelt prayer acknowledging God’s greatness.

questions.question: A parent wants to teach their child about God’s strength. According to Psalms 8, what example illustrates God’s power?
options: God ordains strength even from the mouths of babes and sucklings.
Strength comes from human wisdom alone.
Babies are weak and powerless without God.
questions.correctAnswer: God ordains strength even from the mouths of babes and sucklings.
questions.explanation: Psalms 8:2 explains that God uses even the weakest, like children, to still enemies, showing His sovereign power working through the humble.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 8 teaches that humans have no special place or authority in creation.
questions.explanation: Psalms 8:5-6 clearly states that humans are made a little lower than angels and given dominion over all creation, affirming their special role.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 8 encourages believers to reflect on God’s creation as a way to deepen their faith and trust.
questions.explanation: Psalms 8:3 highlights the heavens, moon, and stars as God’s work, inviting believers to consider creation to strengthen their faith.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "When I consider thy heavens, the work of thy fingers, the moon and the stars, which thou hast _______;"
questions.explanation: Psalms 8:3 uses the word 'ordained' to describe God’s intentional creation and control over the heavens, moon, and stars.

questions.question: How does Psalms 8 guide believers in understanding their role in church fellowship and serving others?
options: God has given humans dominion over His works, implying a responsibility to serve and care for others.
Serving others is optional and unrelated to God’s purpose.
Believers should seek personal gain before serving.
Dominion means ruling over others harshly.
questions.correctAnswer: God has given humans dominion over His works, implying a responsibility to serve and care for others.
questions.explanation: Psalms 8:6-7 emphasizes human authority over creation, which can be applied as a call to stewardship and loving service in community and church life.

questions.question: What does Psalms 8 teach about humility in the face of God’s greatness?
options: Though God’s name is excellent in all the earth, He is mindful of humans.
God is distant and unconcerned about humanity.
Humans should boast about their achievements above God.
God’s greatness makes humans insignificant and worthless.
questions.correctAnswer: Though God’s name is excellent in all the earth, He is mindful of humans.
questions.explanation: Psalms 8:1 and 8:4 show God’s greatness and His mindful care for humans, teaching believers humility but also assurance of God’s attention.

questions.question: A believer struggles with envy over others' success. How does Psalms 8 help correct this attitude?
options: Remember that God crowns each person with glory and honor, giving unique dignity.
Success is the only measure of God’s blessing.
Others’ achievements mean God loves them more.
Envy is acceptable as a motivation to compete.
questions.correctAnswer: Remember that God crowns each person with glory and honor, giving unique dignity.
questions.explanation: Psalms 8:5 teaches that God crowns humans with glory and honor, reminding believers of their inherent worth and calling to contentment.

questions.question: How does Psalms 8 speak to believers about honesty and integrity in their daily lives?
options: Since God has put all things under man’s feet, believers should act responsibly with integrity.
Honesty is optional when managing God’s creation.
Integrity is irrelevant in daily work.
Dominion means using deception to succeed.
questions.correctAnswer: Since God has put all things under man’s feet, believers should act responsibly with integrity.
questions.explanation: Psalms 8:6-8 reminds believers of their God-given authority, which involves honest stewardship and integrity in all areas of life.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 8 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 8.

questions.question: In Psalms 8:5, man is described as being made a little lower than whom?
questions.explanation: Psalms 8:5 states that man was made 'a little lower than the angels' and crowned with glory and honor.

questions.question: Which celestial bodies are mentioned in Psalms 8:3 as the work of God's fingers?
questions.explanation: Psalms 8:3 specifically mentions 'the moon and the stars' as the work of God's fingers.

questions.question: According to Psalms 8:6, what has God put under man's feet?
questions.explanation: Psalms 8:6 says God put 'all things under his feet,' indicating dominion over everything God made.

questions.question: What is the repeated phrase that emphasizes the excellence of the LORD's name in Psalms 8?
options: How excellent is thy name in all the earth!
questions.correctAnswer: How excellent is thy name in all the earth!
questions.explanation: Psalms 8:1 and Psalms 8:9 both open and close with the phrase 'O LORD our Lord, how excellent is thy name in all the earth!' framing the Psalm.

questions.question: Psalms 8:2 speaks of strength ordained from the mouth of whom?
questions.explanation: The verse emphasizes that divine strength comes from the weak or vulnerable, 'babes and sucklings.'

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'Thou hast made him to have dominion over the works of thy _____.'
questions.explanation: Psalms 8:6 explicitly uses the phrase 'works of thy hands,' indicating God's creative acts over which man has dominion.

questions.question: Which literary device is evident in Psalms 8 by repeating the phrase about the LORD's name at the beginning and end?
questions.explanation: The Psalm employs a chiastic structure by framing the text with the same phrase in verses 1 and 9, emphasizing God's name's excellence.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 8 portrays man as having authority over both terrestrial and aquatic creatures.
questions.explanation: Psalms 8:7-8 detail that man has dominion over 'sheep and oxen,' 'beasts of the field,' 'fowl of the air,' and 'fish of the sea.'

questions.question: The phrase 'the work of thy fingers' in Psalms 8:3 metaphorically highlights what aspect of creation?
questions.explanation: Referring to creation as the work of God's fingers suggests a delicate, personal, and skilled act of creation.

questions.question: In the cultural context of the ancient Near East, how is the dominion described in Psalms 8:6 significant?
options: It reflects humanity’s God-given stewardship over creation
It indicates political power over nations
It refers only to spiritual authority
It denotes the priestly role in worship
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects humanity’s God-given stewardship over creation
questions.explanation: The passage emphasizes divine granting of authority to humans over nature, consistent with ancient Near Eastern concepts of stewardship under a deity.

questions.question: Which New Testament passage most directly alludes to the theme of man’s exalted status in Psalms 8:5?
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:6-8 quotes Psalms 8 and discusses humanity’s exalted status just below angels and the authority over creation.

questions.question: The rhetorical question in Psalms 8:4 ('What is man, that thou art mindful of him?') serves what literary purpose?
options: To express wonder at God’s attention to humans
questions.correctAnswer: To express wonder at God’s attention to humans
questions.explanation: The question highlights amazement that God, the vast Creator, would be mindful of frail humanity.

questions.question: Which Hebrew word translated as 'dominion' in Psalms 8:6 signifies authority and rulership?
questions.explanation: The Hebrew word 'radah' used here means 'to rule' or 'have dominion,' emphasizing mankind’s God-ordained authority over creation.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 8 was written by Solomon as a song of praise to the temple musicians.
questions.explanation: Psalms 8 is attributed to David, not Solomon, as indicated in the header 'A Psalm of David' (Psalms 8:1).

questions.question: Which theme in Psalms 8 foreshadows the New Testament concept of Christ’s humanity and exaltation?
options: The establishment of a physical temple
questions.explanation: The Psalm’s depiction of man crowned with glory and authority foreshadows Christ’s incarnation and exaltation as the perfect man and King.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 8 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 8 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 8:1, where has God set His glory?
questions.explanation: Psalms 8:1 states, 'who hast set thy glory above the heavens.' This highlights God's transcendence and majesty. Consistent with Isaiah 6:1, Psalm 19:1, and Hebrews 1:3, God's glory is supreme and transcendent.

questions.question: In Psalms 8:2, what is ordained from the mouth of babes and sucklings?
questions.explanation: Psalms 8:2 says, 'Out of the mouth of babes and sucklings hast thou ordained strength because of thine enemies.' This suggests God uses even the weakest to confound the strong, as echoed in Matthew 21:16 and 1 Corinthians 1:27.

questions.question: What celestial bodies does the Psalmist mention as the work of God's fingers in Psalms 8:3?
questions.explanation: Psalms 8:3 refers to 'the moon and the stars, which thou hast ordained,' emphasizing God's creative power. This aligns with Job 38:7, Genesis 1:16, and Nehemiah 9:6 which affirm God as Creator of the cosmos.

questions.question: What question does the Psalmist ask about man in Psalms 8:4?
options: What is man, that thou art mindful of him?
Where is wisdom to be found?
questions.correctAnswer: What is man, that thou art mindful of him?
questions.explanation: Psalms 8:4 asks, 'What is man, that thou art mindful of him? and the son of man, that thou visitest him?' This profound question underscores human insignificance contrasted with divine care, echoed in Hebrews 2:6-8 and Job 7:17.

questions.question: According to Psalms 8:5, how is man described in relation to angels?
options: A little lower than the angels
questions.correctAnswer: A little lower than the angels
questions.explanation: Psalms 8:5 states, 'For thou hast made him a little lower than the angels,' indicating humanity's exalted but subordinate position. This is consistent with Hebrews 2:7, which quotes this Psalm to describe Christ’s incarnation.

questions.question: What has God crowned man with, according to Psalms 8:5?
questions.explanation: Psalms 8:5 affirms that God has crowned man with 'glory and honour,' signifying dignity bestowed by God. This is aligned with Genesis 1:26, Romans 3:23, and 1 Corinthians 15:49 on mankind's created dignity and fallen need for restoration.

questions.question: What dominion has God given to man as described in Psalms 8:6?
options: Dominion over the works of His hands
questions.correctAnswer: Dominion over the works of His hands
questions.explanation: Psalms 8:6 says, 'Thou madest him to have dominion over the works of thy hands,' indicating mankind’s stewardship role over creation. This echoes Genesis 1:28 and is foundational for biblical anthropology and stewardship theology.

questions.question: Which of the following animals is NOT explicitly mentioned in Psalms 8:7-8 as being under man's dominion?
questions.explanation: Psalms 8:7-8 lists 'sheep and oxen,' 'beasts of the field,' 'fowl of the air,' and 'fish of the sea,' but does not mention serpents. This illustrates the comprehensive scope of human stewardship over creation, matching Genesis 1:26-28.

questions.question: How many times is the phrase 'O LORD our Lord, how excellent is thy name in all the earth!' repeated in Psalms 8?
questions.explanation: Psalms 8:1 and Psalms 8:9 both begin and end with 'O LORD our Lord, how excellent is thy name in all the earth!' framing the Psalm with praise. This literary structure emphasizes God's majesty, seen also in Psalms 113:1 and Revelation 4:11.

questions.question: What theological significance does the dominion of man over creation in Psalms 8:6-8 have for Christian doctrine?
options: It affirms mankind's role as God’s steward and reflects the imago Dei
It teaches that man is divine
It shows that creation is hostile to man
It denies human responsibility for the earth
questions.correctAnswer: It affirms mankind's role as God’s steward and reflects the imago Dei
questions.explanation: Psalms 8:6-8 highlights human dominion given by God, reflecting the Imago Dei (Genesis 1:26-27), affirming stewardship and responsibility, foundational in systematic theology and Christian ethics as seen in Colossians 1:16-17.

questions.question: How does Psalms 8:4-5 contribute to Christological understanding in the New Testament?
options: It is cited in Hebrews 2 to describe Christ’s incarnation and exaltation
It denies the divinity of Christ
It teaches that Christ is an angel
It focuses solely on Old Testament Israel
questions.correctAnswer: It is cited in Hebrews 2 to describe Christ’s incarnation and exaltation
questions.explanation: Hebrews 2:6-9 quotes Psalms 8:4-6 to demonstrate Christ's temporary humiliation and ultimate exaltation, affirming His role as the God-man, central to Christology and soteriology.

questions.question: What apologetic argument can be drawn from Psalms 8:3 about the origin of the universe?
options: The ordered creation of moon and stars points to an intelligent Designer
The universe is chaotic and random
The cosmos came into being by chance
questions.correctAnswer: The ordered creation of moon and stars points to an intelligent Designer
questions.explanation: Psalms 8:3 emphasizes God’s handiwork in the heavens, supporting the teleological argument for God’s existence found also in Romans 1:20 and Job 38:4-7.

questions.question: In theological anthropology, what does Psalms 8:4-5 reveal about human nature?
options: Humans are created with dignity just below angels but are objects of God's mindful care
Humans are insignificant and ignored by God
questions.correctAnswer: Humans are created with dignity just below angels but are objects of God's mindful care
questions.explanation: Psalms 8:4-5 highlights human dignity and God’s care, foundational for understanding the imago Dei and human purpose, consistent with Genesis 1:26-27 and Hebrews 2:6-7.

questions.question: What eschatological hope can be inferred from the dominion given to man in Psalms 8:6-8?
options: The restoration of mankind’s dominion under Christ’s reign
Creation will be destroyed with no restoration
Dominion belongs only to angels in the end
questions.correctAnswer: The restoration of mankind’s dominion under Christ’s reign
questions.explanation: The dominion in Psalms 8 anticipates ultimate restoration in Christ, as seen in Revelation 5:13, 1 Corinthians 15:25-27, where Christ reigns and restores creation’s order.

questions.question: How does Psalms 8 emphasize God's attribute of sovereignty?
options: By showing God’s glory above the heavens and dominion given to man
By showing God as distant and uninvolved
By focusing only on human achievements
By denying God’s control over nature
questions.correctAnswer: By showing God’s glory above the heavens and dominion given to man
questions.explanation: Psalms 8:1 and 8:6 portray God as sovereign over all creation, sovereignly granting dominion, consistent with Psalm 103:19, Isaiah 40:12, and Colossians 1:16-17.
